This data encompasses both surface water (e.g., river levels, streamflow) and groundwater. The ability to refine queries and choose desired output makes it convenient for obtaining daily surface water parameter data from USGS streamgaging stations nationwide. This method is crucial as it ensures comprehensive water-resources data availability, enabling effective management, research, and public access to essential hydrological information. description:
The United States Geological Survey (USGS) is responsible for gathering water-resources data from around 1.5 million locations across the United States, including District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. This extensive dataset encompasses both surface water and groundwater information.

Surface water data, a primary focus of USGS, include measurements such as gage height (stage) and streamflow (discharge). These parameters are typically obtained from significant bodies of water like major rivers, lakes, and reservoirs. Access to current and historical surface water data can be found on the National Water Information System (NWIS) website.

Users can retrieve this data by selecting the desired category, such as surface water or groundwater, followed by specifying a geographic area of interest. The NWIS webpage then offers further refinement options, allowing users to choose specific information and define their preferred output format. As an example, daily data for various surface water parameters can be obtained from USGS streamgaging stations nationwide.

Users can access these datasets online via the URL: http://waterdata.usgs.gov/nwis/. The NWIS web interface makes it convenient for researchers, planners, and other stakeholders to access reliable and up-to-date information on water resources across the United States.
